info.title: ERI - (E)xternal (R)etrieval (I)nterface â¸º 2.0-design
info.description:
This API serves as a contract between LLM tools like AI Studio and any external data sources for RAG
(retrieval-augmented generation). The tool, e.g., AI Studio acts as the client (the augmentation and
generation parts) and the data sources act as the server (the retrieval part). The data
sources implement some form of data retrieval and return a suitable context to the LLM tool.
The LLM tool, in turn, handles the integration of appropriate LLMs (augmentation & generation).
Data sources can be document or graph databases, or even a file system, for example. They
will likely implement an appropriate retrieval process by using some kind of embedding.
However, this API does not inherently require any embedding, as data processing is
implemented decentralized by the data sources.

The client expects that all fields in the JSON responses from an ERI server are named according
to camel case or Pascal case conventions. The client's JSON objects for requests use camel case
for the field names.

post.summary: Get a chat completion from the ERI server's LLM provider.
post.description:
Get a chat completion from the ERI server's LLM provider, based on the provided messages.
The response is a stream of SSE (Server-Sent Events) messages. This API is compatible
with the OpenAI chat completion API. Differences are: (1) Only a list of messages
is accepted as input. Other parameters, like model name, temperature, etc., are
not supported. (2) The response data structure might be a subset of the OpenAI
response data structure.

parameters.name: sessionId
parameters.description: The retrieval session ID to use for context. The retrieval process must be done.

parameters.name: eri-version
parameters.description: The API version to use. This must be set to '2.0-design'.

requestBody.description: The list of chat messages to base the completion on.

get.summary: Get the security requirements for this ERI server.
get.description:
Represents the security requirements for this ERI server.

The list of forbidden providers takes precedence over the list of allowed providers. If a provider is in both lists, it is considered forbidden. Example: when you disallow all Asian providers and allow all providers, the result is that all non-Asian providers are allowed.

When both lists are empty, it means that all providers are allowed.

You can use the allowed IP ranges to restrict access to LLM providers from specific IP ranges. If the list is empty, there are no restrictions on IP ranges. You can use CIDR notation to specify IP ranges (e.g., 192.168.1.0/30), single IP addresses (e.g., 192.168.0.1), or specify a range using a start and end IP address (e.g., 10.0.0.1-10.0.0.255).

This is useful if you want to allow access to LLM providers only from specific networks, e.g., your corporate network or a VPN. In practice, this means that only self-hosted or on-premise LLM providers can be used, as public LLM providers do not publish their IP addresses. You should use this feature in combination with allowed providers set to self-hosted providers only.

AuthField.description:
An authentication field.

* `NONE` - No authentication field.
* `USERNAME` - The username field.
* `PASSWORD` - The password field.
* `TOKEN` - The authentication token field.
* `KERBEROS_TICKET` - The Kerberos ticket field.

fieldName.description: The field name in the authentication request.

AuthFieldMapping.description: The mapping between an AuthField and the field name in the authentication request.

AuthMethod.description:
An authentication method.

* `NONE` - No authentication method.
* `KERBEROS` - Kerberos authentication.
* `USERNAME_PASSWORD` - Username and password authentication.
* `TOKEN` - Token-based authentication.

success.description: True, when the authentication was successful.

token.description: The token to use for further requests.

message.description: When the authentication was not successful, this contains the reason.

AuthResponse.description: The response to an authentication request.

authFieldMappings.description:
A list of field mappings for the authentication method. The client must know,
            e.g., how the password field is named in the request.

AuthScheme.description: Describes one authentication scheme for this data source.

content.description: The text content of the message.

role.description: The role of the message, e.g., "user", "assistant", or "system".

ChatMessage.description: A message in a chat conversation.

contentBlocks.description: The content blocks in this chat thread.

ChatThread.description: A chat thread, which is a list of content blocks.

Citation.description: A citation for a piece of information.

content.description: The content of the block. Remember that images and other media are base64 encoded.

ContentBlock.description: A block of content of a chat thread.

name.description:
The name of the source, e.g., a document name, database name,
            collection name, etc.

category.description:
What are the contents of the source? For example, is it a
            dictionary, a book chapter, business concept, a paper, etc.

path.description:
The path to the content, e.g., a URL, a file path, a path in a
            graph database, etc.

confidenceScore.description:
An optional confidence score between 0 and 1 indicating
            the confidence of the match. A higher score indicates higher confidence.

matchedContent.description:
The content that matched the user prompt. For text, you
            return the matched text and, e.g., three words before and after it.

surroundingContent.description:
The surrounding content of the matched content.
            For text, you may return, e.g., one sentence or paragraph before and after
            the matched content.

links.description:
Links to related content, e.g., links to Wikipedia articles,
            links to sources, etc.

Context.description: Matching context returned by the data source as a result of a retrieval request.

name.description: The name of the data source, e.g., "Internal Organization Documents."

description.description:
A short description of the data source. What kind of data does it contain?
            What is the data source used for?

id.description: The id of this data source. Use this index to refer to the data source in other API calls.

name.description: The name of the data source, e.g., "Internal Organization Documents."

embeddingType.description:
What kind of embedding is used. For example, "Transformer Embedding," "Contextual Word
            Embedding," "Graph Embedding," etc.

embeddingName.description:
Name the embedding used. This can be a library, a framework, or the name of the used
            algorithm.

description.description: A short description of the embedding. Describe what the embedding is doing.

usedWhen.description:
Describe when the embedding is used. For example, when the user prompt contains certain
            keywords, or anytime?

link.description: A link to the embedding's documentation or the source code. Might be null.

EmbeddingInfo.description:
Represents information about the used embedding for this data source. The purpose of this information is to give the
interested user an idea of what kind of embedding is used and what it does.

llmTaskId.description: The ID of the LLM task.

LLMResponse.description: The response from a client-side LLM task.

id.description:
A unique identifier for the retrieval process. This can be a GUID, a unique name,
            or an increasing integer.

name.description:
The name of the retrieval process, e.g.,
            "Keyword-Based Wikipedia Article Retrieval".

description.description:
A short description of the retrieval process. What kind of retrieval
            process is it?

link.description:
A link to the retrieval process's documentation, paper, Wikipedia article, or
            the source code. Might be null.

mustUseERIServerLLMProvider.description:
Indicates whether this retrieval process depends on its
            own LLM provider, which is hosted on the ERI server side. When true, the ERI client must not
            provide an LLM provider for this retrieval process, as it will be ignored. Instead, the ERI client
            will use the chat completion endpoint of the ERI server for the generation. Another case when this
            is true is for confidential data sources, where the retrieval process must
            ensure that no data is sent to any third-party LLM provider.

parametersDescription.description:
A dictionary that describes the parameters of the retrieval
            process. The key is the parameter name,
            and the value is a description of the parameter. Although each parameter will be sent as a string,
            the description should indicate the
            expected type and range, e.g., 0.0 to 1.0 for a float parameter.

embeddings.description:
A list of embeddings used in this retrieval process. It might be empty
            in case no embedding is used.

RetrievalInfo.description: Information about a retrieval process, which this data source implements.

llmTaskId.description:
The ID of the LLM task that was created for this step. When the retrieval process
            does not need to call the user's LLM, this will be Guid.Empty.

RetrievalProcessStepResponse.description: A response for a step in the retrieval process.

RetrievalProcessStepType.description:
The type of action the client should take for a retrieval process step.

* `NO_ACTION_NEEDED` - No action is needed from the client.
* `ASK_LLM` - The client should send a query to the LLM to get more information.
* `DONE` - The retrieval process is complete.

current.description: The current progress value. When the type is CONTINUOUS, this is ignored.

total.description:
The total value of the progress. When the type is CONTINUOUS, this is ignored.
            When the type is PERCENTAGE, this is always 100.

RetrievalProgress.description: Represents the progress of a retrieval operation.

RetrievalProgressType.description:
The type of progress indication for a retrieval operation.

* `PERCENTAGE` - The progress is indicated as a percentage (0-100).
* `NUMBER_OF_ITEMS` - The progress is indicated as the number of items processed out of a total number of items.
* `CONTINUOUS` - The progress is indicated as a continuous stream of updates. We might not know the
            total amount of work to be done.

latestUserPrompt.description: The latest user prompt that AI Studio received.

retrievalProcessId.description:
Optional. The ID of the retrieval process that the data source should use.
            When null, the data source chooses an appropriate retrieval process. Selecting a retrieval process is optional
            for AI Studio users. Most users do not specify a retrieval process.

parameters.description:
A dictionary of parameters that the data source should use for the retrieval process.
            Although each parameter will be sent as a string, the retrieval process specifies the expected type and range.

maxMatches.description:
The maximum number of matches that the data source should return. AI Studio uses
            any value below 1 to indicate that the data source should return as many matches as appropriate.

RetrievalRequest.description: The retrieval request sent by AI Studio.

contexts.description:
The list of contexts retrieved. This list may be empty when this retrieval
            process is a conclusive answer retrieval process (aka deep research).

conclusiveAnswer.description:
A conclusive answer if this retrieval process is a conclusive answer
            retrieval process (aka deep research). This will be null or empty when the retrieval process performed
            classic retrieval.

citations.description: The list of citations. This list may be null or empty.

moreResultsAvailable.description:
Indicates whether more results are available for retrieval.
            This is useful for pagination scenarios.

RetrievalResult.description: The result of a retrieval operation.

RetrievalResultState.description:
Represents the state of a retrieval result.

* `UNKNOWN` - The state of the retrieval result is unknown.
* `PROCESS_STILL_ONGOING` - The retrieval process is still ongoing. Thus, results are not yet available.
* `RESULTS_READY` - The retrieval process has completed, and results are ready to be accessed.
* `NO_RESULTS_FOUND` - There are no results found or left to retrieve.

RetrievalState.description:
Represents the state of a retrieval operation.

* `NOT_STARTED` - The retrieval process has not started yet.
* `ONGOING` - The retrieval process is ongoing.
* `DONE` - The retrieval process has completed successfully.

RetrievalStatus.description: The status of a retrieval operation.

Role.description:
Possible roles of a content block in a chat thread.

* `NONE` - No role specified.
* `UNKNOWN` - Role is unknown.
* `SYSTEM` - System role, e.g., instructions to the AI model.
* `USER` - User role, e.g., user input.
* `AI` - AI role, e.g., AI-generated response.
* `AGENT` - Content generated by an AI agent.

allowedIPRanges.description: The list of allowed IP ranges for LLM providers.

SecurityRequirements.description:
Represents the security requirements for this ERI server.



The list of forbidden providers takes precedence over the list of allowed providers.
If a provider is in both lists, it is considered forbidden. Example: when you disallow all Asian
providers and allow all providers, the result is that all non-Asian providers are allowed.


            
When both lists are empty, it means that all providers are allowed.


            
You can use the allowed IP ranges to restrict access to LLM providers from specific IP ranges.
If the list is empty, there are no restrictions on IP ranges. You can use CIDR notation to specify
IP ranges (e.g., 192.168.1.0/30), single IP addresses (e.g., 192.168.0.1), or specify a range using
a start and end IP address (e.g., 10.0.0.1-10.0.0.255).


            
This is useful if you want to allow access to LLM providers only from specific networks,
e.g., your corporate network or a VPN. In practice, this means that only self-hosted
or on-premise LLM providers can be used, as public LLM providers do not publish
their IP addresses. You should use this feature in combination with allowed providers
set to self-hosted providers only.

description.description: A short description of the tool.
